posts.name: graywhaler
posts.cooked: I’ve looked over the description for the Candi on CTR’s website and am struggling to figure out what I would use it for. I get that it can integrate a PWM device into a CAN loop but am not sure what that really buys me. Any thoughts out there? Can anyone describe how they’ve used it?

posts.name: Nick Wight
posts.cooked: 254 explains in their behind the bumpers one of the ways they used the CANdi this year.

posts.name: MetabolicCloth
posts.cooked: The big benefit of the CANdi in my opinion is that it allows you to remotely land multiple Digital I/O anywhere you currently run your can bus. Makes adding I/O to the end of an arm or remote location easier.

MetabolicCloth:

Makes adding I/O to the end of an arm or remote location easier.

3414 had to run a PWM cable after our CANdi failed to work for some IR sensors in 2025. Distinctly wasn’t very easy and a bit frustrating.

Maybe it’s been fixed since this was early in the life cycle.

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked:
On our champs robot, we ran only a single power and single CAN pair to our arm. We were able to tap power from a Kraken to power both a retro reflective sensor and the CANdi. The retro reflective sensor signal channels were then then connected to the CANdi.

This greatly simplified the wiring we had to do- there was no need to run extra sensor channels through our elevator or through our arm.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked:
if you run out of io on the rio I guess and the aforementioned io extension to far locations.

maybe also for connecting encoders as well.

on our competition robot though, we wired the ir distance sensor on the arm to the spark flex driving the arm motor.

posts.name: Marcus
posts.cooked: What’s the setup to “tap power from a kraken”? Could you send a picture of how it’s done?

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked: We just use the Kraken Powerpole Adapter ( https://docs.wcproducts.com/kraken-x60/accessories/powerpole-adapter-board ) and use the Molex SL 4 pin to grab power and CAN for the CANdi.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
This is kind of the key here – you aren’t allowed to do this for most of the motors and motor controllers, but you can tap power from Krakens if you’re using that specific adapter board.  Otherwise, you’re still stuck running a pair of wires up to the superstructure for CANdi/sensor power, and the savings are pretty minimal at that point.

You can do a lesser version of this with some of the other motor controllers that give you a 5V or 3.3V supply and analog/digital inputs, but it’s not as versatile or robust as the direct tap from the board.  You might be able to run a small step-up DC-DC converter off of a 5V rail to power a CANdi from a SPARK MAX, Flex or Talon FXS.  I don’t know if that’s asking for trouble or not.

posts.name: Bryce Roethel
posts.cooked:
We used a CANdi on our end effector for both an optical beam break sensor and for a REV throughbore encoder ( WCP Throughbore powered by CANcoder did not ship in time), which we found simplified wiring and sidestepped issues with running PWM over a long distance back to the RIO. We configured the beam break as a limit switch which was ignored by most control modes, excluding when we were intaking so that we could increase the speed at which the end effector receives coral without running into timing issues otherwise experienced when attempting to implement on the RIO at 50hz.

We also used a CANdi for our elevator limit switches, for which Phoenix 6 provides a LimitAutosetPosition config option  that can passively zero a configured motor’s position, which is a nice code simplification.

Notably, these are all “nice to haves”, but there’s certainly cheaper alternatives that would achieve the same results. In our case, we decided the convenience outweighed the price.

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked:
Absolutely on the point about the easiest remote mechanism use case being with Krakens.

I do want to stress however the utility of having very short sensor runs to minimize noise in the signal itself. If your plan is to run a sensor from a remote mechanism straight to the Rio (think 4+ feet), you will need to pay attention to cable shielding and potentially do some sort of filtering on the Rio side. There is generally no need to do any of that if you are able to have very short signal runs to the CANdi, with CAN doing the heavy lifting when dealing with signal noise to the Rio.
